I am 47, married and have two boys (12 and 14).  I work full time but have not worked since Dec, but hope to return part-time tormmorrow, and work between treatments, I work in medicail office so flu season has been concern for my onc.  I had bilateral masectomy with TEs on Dec 2, and additional axillary node disection on Dec 28 (hopefully my stats show up on bottom?).  No issues with surgerys, but still discomfort from TEs and worried sick about getting LE. I am having TAC x 6, I have completed 2 rounds and next round is on Friday.  Side effects very much like everyone else.  I had horrible indigestion after 1st round and was given Aciphex rx which has worked well, both rounds started with consipation but have figured out how to manage, and take nausea meds on the clock.  No appitite for 1st week, followed by 2 ok weeks.  I have had issues with sleep and now taking ambien which helps and also occasionally add zanax. Someone mentioned scans, I had an ovary "light up" on my PET scan, normal size and I will have another scan after this weeks chemo, I am praying it was just a functional ovary since I was still very regular with periods and this was mid cycle.  I am BRAC 1, neg and BRAC 2 test was mutation of unknown significance, anyone else have this?  Well enough for now, just wanted to introduce myself and join your group.  Best to all this week! Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 07:26PM christine47 wrote: citykitty-  I got the xanax rx from my onc.  I asked his nurse at my 1st chemo if he ever prescribed anything for anxiety, and he came by and gave me rx.  I was extremely disturbed about my hair loss and my 1st few outings with the wig I had to take a pill so I did not fall apart.  It is very fast acting.  I need it less and less, sometimes just knowing I have if I need it is enough.  My onc has been so great, he believes in doing whatever you need to get thru ( I also have rx for ambien and vicodin if needed).  I saw him today for exam and labs before this weeks chemo.  He told me it seemed like my chemo had gone so fast (easy for him to say).  How are things post exchange?? I plan to go back next month. Julie-  congrats on your final Taxol!  I feel the same about my last round of TAC this week, I can live with the SE, knowing this is the final week of yuck.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 10:06AM christine47 wrote: Jcoutee,--You are so young, if you had clear margins and no positive nodes, your outcome will be the same with lumpectomy and rads as with masectomy.  You can always change your mind later, talk with your surgeon and onc before you make any decisions, you can never go back.  Your also BRAC neg, in your favor too.  I will be asking about the effexor, forgot yesterday, I know a side effect is lack of sex drive, I am currently bald, grumpy, and have steroid induced rage, what sex drive?? yorelh--Welcome, I had BMX with tissue expanders prior to chemo, I have done well, and almost fully expanded, I hate the TEs, but they look good and I understand the implants will be much more comfortable.  I am 47, done with kids and had my chance to breast feed.  You do loose sensation with the masectomy, which is a bummer, but I am more bothered by loss of sensation in my arm from axillary node disection.  Good luck to you with your decision. If you have any questions I can answer let me know.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 12:29PM christine47 wrote: jcoutee,--I had bilateral masectomy, according to my surgeon you can still have reoccurance but rare.  They can not take 100% of breast tissue, but very close.  I also choose to have BMX to avoid rads, since I had one positive node.  No matter what you choose, know in your heart you are making the right choice, you will do well. tsundermann-- I plan to make more changes post treatment.  I have gained about 6-8lbs since starting treatment, frustating, but trying not to obsess about it.  Mostly from more carbs (bread, cereal, potatoes, etc), just not tolerating my salads, fruit, etc with chemo.  I know I can do better once my reflux and nausea improve, and plan too.  I want the extra weight off before my exchange surgery.  I am not exercising like I was prior to winter and BC, but plan to get back on track there too, for me this is as important for my physical as mental health.  I am taking major doses of vitamin D, 50,000 units per week.  I went from 10 in Jan, to 38 this week, so it is working.  My onc also told me to get alittle sun every day (can you believe that).  I don't believe anything we did caused our BC either, I took fertility meds, probably increased risk, but would not trade my kids for not having BC! Hope you are all doing well, I am having 5th chemo tomorrow, last one on April 28th.  Two more bad hangovers and I am done, done, done!!

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 07:09AM christine47 wrote: melissa/moe, I am so sorry you are having such a rough time with the AC.  I hope your onc can help you with the side effects.  I was so frustrated/sick after my 3rd round of TAC, I was going to quit (discussed with my onc).  Just felt like hell, not to mentioned acted like the devil.  For the last 3 of my treatments we changed the nausea meds and I decieded that if I needed to sleep thru the side effects, I would.  In addition to the nausea meds, I took my ambien, xanax and vicodin, round the clock.  Yes, I slept for about 2 -3 days after treatment, but got thru.  My DH and kids realized they just would not see me for a few days.  I would not even let my husband sleep in our bed (only the cat), until I came out of my chemo sick.  I am sure your kids and husband will understand.  For me the mental part of feeling bad was maybe worse than being physically sick, such a loss of control, just felt emotionally defeated.  You will feel so much better once you complete your last treatment, you can do it! I do not have ativan, instead xanax, and I have taken both the xanan and ambien at night. Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 12:25PM christine47 wrote: Moe,  I think you can expect a relatively short surgery without the reconstruction, about 2 hours.  Because of the numbness you will probably have minimal discomfort (notice I did not say pain).  Taking you medication before discomfort helps, I also had an antibiotic to take to prevent infection.  Buying a camisole for after surgery ifs helpful, most insurances will/ must pay for these, and I bet your have met your deductable (ha, ha).  I got mine while I was in the hospital, but was fitted for it at preoperative visit.  They have pockets for drains, and also fluffy stuff for the bra part, so you have something to wear and not be flat, later.  I also had to wear a binder under mine for a couple of weeks, but that was my plastic surgeons instructions. I spent 2 nights in the hospital, more because of nausea and long surgery time, maybe you will go home in a day or the same day.  Having someone with you at home for a few days would be helpful.  Also extra pillows for your bed, lying flat was abit uncomfortable at first.  Also tops that button or zip, you can not and should not reach over your head at first, and pants or shorts with elastic waist bands are great.  I was permitted to take a quick shower the next day, as they used glue on the incisions. I am done with my surgery (except implant exchange), and like you worry about everything.  I wait for the day when I can wake up and not think about breast cancer.  At least I no longer think about it every minute, just every hour. Are you having your surgery at a large medical center in NC, I had mine at Baptist Medical Center?

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 05:35PM christine47 wrote: Melissa, I have been getting TAC, I have had to take the nausea meds on the clock for the 1st 3-4 days, I use zofran every 8 hrs, and occasionally take compazine for break thru nausea.  Not much appetite, except for bland foods, until day 5-6, I try to keep something on my stomach, and eat anything I can.  Heartburn has been an issue, my onc gave me rx for Protonix, which helps soo much.  Water is hard for me to drink straight, so I mix in alittle juice or something for flavor.  Also better time with drinking water if I have a lifesaver or hard candy in my mouth.  Otherwise I get some nausea from straight water.  I also have found ice tea to go down well.  I was a diet coke addict, and have no taste for it.  I have experienced bone pain and have increased discomfort and fullness with TEs, I take some pain meds and this seems to help, fortunately not everyone will have bone pain with neulasta. No allergic reactions, but I get so much dexamethasone before and during.  I am moody and have cryed on day 3 last 2 treatments, I have told my DH and boys (12 and 14), to just stay clear, make their own dinner, etc.  They have now figured out the routine.  I know its harder for your younger children to understand. Then by day 6, I am back to my "normal" self.  Maybe you can take a few days off after your next treatment?  How many do you need to do?
